Description: Marble fragment of profile with spiral. The cross-section of the profile is on the preserved upper part almost circular (radius 4,1 cm) and opens on the lower part. It could therefore have built an Ionic cyma and not an ovolo moulding. The lateral surface of the cymas is cut flatly on the left side. From there a spiral and flat cove is worked in and is framed by bars. On the bush-hammered upper side of the fragment, two scratch lines run parallel to the front side. The light grey marble fragment is almost not weathered, however, fractured on the back and lower side.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'second temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: The cyma has in the better preserved upper area a considerably bigger cross-section radius, however, its curvature is rounder and fuller than the marble cymas found in the sanctuary of Apollo (1900.2-14.23; B 412; B 413; B 414). The special decoration with the spiral on the heading joint indicates the usage of the original piece on a special location in the building: maybe the cyma bluntly impinges here on a flat wall. Published (Petrie 1886, Pl. 14, 6; W. B. Dinsmoor 1913, BCH 37, 15); Altkamp 1999, 136 NB 566)
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B419)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XIV, no. 6)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no.33, p.336, pl. 24)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.42) (Phase 3)
